Bangladeshi authorities have stated that vaccinated arrivals from some international locations, including Armenia, Bulgaria, Estonia, Georgia, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Mongolia, the Palestinian Territories, Romania, Serbia, Slovenia, and Ukraine, must quarantine at their residence for seven days, while unvaccinated entrants from these locations must quarantine at a designated facility for seven days at their own expense. Authorities allow vaccinated arrivals from all other locations to enter without having to quarantine, while unvaccinated entrants must quarantine at their residence for 14 days. Symptomatic arrivals from any location or with any vaccination status must isolate at a designated facility.    https://archive.ph/Uv7Te

Officials continue to enforce nationwide restrictions as of Nov. 29 to curb the spread of COVID-19.  Officials continue to conduct random COVID-19 testing for travellers, students, teachers, transporters, and business personnel every two weeks.   Inter-district travellers must register via the Check Post Management System. Authorities continue to require people who travel from high-risk to low-risk areas to quarantine for seven days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211221065600/https:/www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/550486/bhutan-authorities-continuing-to-enforce-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-nov-29-update-36

Officials continue to enforce nationwide restrictions as of Nov. 29 to curb the spread of COVID-19.    International flights to and from Bhutan remain severely limited due to travel restrictions on Bhutanese citizens and carriers, as well as border closures. Bhutanese air carriers, such as Druk Air (KB) and Bhutan Airlines (B3), are operating some flights mainly to repatriate Bhutanese citizens. Fully vaccinated international arrivals can quarantine at designated facilities for 14 days, while unvaccinated entrants are subject to a 21-day quarantine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211221065600/https:/www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/550486/bhutan-authorities-continuing-to-enforce-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-nov-29-update-36

The country will begin the COVID vaccine booster doses for the priority group across the country from 24th December. The priority group includes all residents above the age of 18 in the high-risk areas, elderly above 65 years across the country, persons with chronic medical conditions, all health workers and all outbound travellers above the age of 18.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225

The country will begin the COVID vaccine booster doses for the priority group across the country from 24th December. The priority group includes elderly above 65 years across the country    https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225

The country will begin the COVID vaccine booster doses for the priority group across the country from 24th December. The priority group includes all residents above the age of 18 in the high-risk areas, elderly above 65 years across the country, persons with chronic medical conditions, all health workers and all outbound travellers above the age of 18. According to the ministry, there are close to 230,000 people in the priority group.    The ministry will provide the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines as booster doses for the priority group. However, Astrazeneca and Covishield will be provided as a choice for those who have received these vaccines as their first and second dose.    Similarly, the health ministry on its Facebook page last month shared the ministry is exploring to vaccinate children aged five to eleven years with the Pfizer paediatric vaccines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225

As of November 17, the health ministry has vaccinated 76.8 per cent of its overall population including 93.2 per cent of its adult population and 92.8 per cent of the children aged 12-17 years.      https://web.archive.org/web/20211216122329/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=163225
COVID 19 vaccines are fully funded by the government. No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301155227/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/28-02-21-information-on-covid-19-vaccine-moh/

(PTI)|"  "West Bengal Schools, Colleges May Be Closed  West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee on Wednesday asked officials to review the overall COVID-19 situation in the state. Ms Banerjee, during an administrative review meeting at Sagar Island, also said that schools and colleges might be shut down for some time if the situation so demands.   "COVID-19 cases are on the rise... there are a few Omicron cases also. So, review the situation in the state. We may consider closing down schools and colleges for some time," the minister told officials at the meeting. (PTI)"

"Passengers travelling to India from âat riskâ countries will be de-boarded on priority. These countries are European nations, including UK, as well as South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Brazil, China, Mauritius, New Zealand, Singapore, Hong Kong and Israel."  "Passengers arriving from South Africa, Botswana and Zimbabwe or passengers who have visited any of these three countries in the last 15 days before arrival in Maharashtra, must undergo mandatory institutional quarantine for seven days after giving their RT-PCR test at the airport.    They shall also undergo a second RT-PCR test on the seventh day. If any test is found to be Covid positive, then such passengers will be moved to a hospital with Covid treatment facilities by the civic body or state authorities. If the test is found to be negative on the seventh day, passengers will have to undergo a further seven-day home quarantine."  https://archive.vn/zUU02

Schools across the country resumed in-person classes that were disrupted since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. Commercial flights are operating but with limited availability. The Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) has announced that all domestic flights have resumed, and strict COVID protocols are enforced. Operation of cargo flights, rescue flights, and evacuation flights will be carried out subject to special permission.  Please US embassy link last updated 04/10/21  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     Effective September 24, all fully vaccinated foreigners arriving in Nepal via the immigration office at the airport or a land border can receive on-arrival visas. No quarantine required. Fully-vaccinated travellers travelling to Nepal must present the following documents:  1.Evidence of completion of a 14 day post-COVID-19 vaccination incubation period  2.COVID-19 negative PCR test report obtained within 72 hours of entry into Nepal    On-arrival visas at land border entries are not available to unvaccinated travelers. All unvaccinated and semi-vaccinated travelers must comply with the Government of Nepalâs 10-day quarantine mandate, which requires quarantine at a local hotel at their own cost. A PCR test must be completed and returned negative on 11th day before travelling within the country will be permitted. Such travelers must present the following documents:  1.COVID-19 negative PCR test report obtained within 72 hours of entering the country

All people are eligible for PCR testing in Nepal, with results arriving within 72 hours. These tests are not available at every single hospital, but are accessible.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has approved 5 vaccine (Astrazeneca, Stupnik V, Covaxin, Sinovac, Sinopharm). See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018181222/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    Government set to provide the booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine to those whoâve completed their vaccination at least 3 months ago; Health Minister Birodh Khatiwada has requested all eligible to get the booster dose; students aged 12-18 years will be given the COVID-19 shots in schools from January 2022; government is preparing to administer 200,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccine daily    According to MoH Nepal, as of late November 2021, 31% of the population (including children) have received the 1st dose and 27% are fully vaccinated. See below link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211108223809/https://covid19.mohp.gov.np/covid/englishSituationReport/6188f77ac1b4e_SitRep638_COVID-19_08-11-2021_EN.pdf
